questions.text: An obstructive lesion at which of the following levels will cause only expiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi (D) will cause expiratory stridor.

Other options:

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: In which of the following cellular organelles does HMP shunt occur?
questions.solution: HMP shunt takes place in the cytosol as enzymes needed for the HMP shunt (pentose phosphate) pathway are located in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.

Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: A 53 year old patient came to the ENT OPD with complaints of hearing loss . Rinne’s test done on the  patient shows that air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Weber's test lateralises to the left ear. The diagnosis is?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
When Weber’s test is lateralised to left ear and the Rinne’s test is normal, then there is sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.

  • Rinne's test- To perform Rinne's test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid process. Immediately after the patient stops hearing a tone, the tuning fork is held over the same ear and the patient is asked to report if they hear the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the other side. Positive Rinne's test, means the air conduction is better than bone conduction (AC>BC) in both ears.
  • Weber's test - A vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. Normally, it is heard equally in both ears. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.

questions.text: The government uses the following sign at public places in order to directly or indirectly alter human behaviour. This is an example of _______ approach towards health education.
questions.solution:
The No Smoking sign is an example of regulatory approach.

A regulatory approach with respect to health education is defined as a government intervention, direct or indirect, designed to alter human behaviour.

Regulations may take many forms, from prohibition to imprisonment. Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve personal choices like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

The Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach
Regulatory approach Service approach  Health Education approach Primary health care approach
Government intervention to alter human behavior laws Facilities are provided by the government for use Awareness-> interest->Evaluation The health of the people, for the people, by the people where principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed
Ex: Child marriage Act, No smoking in public places; Helmet law Ex: Government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt Ex: Adoption of ORS for diarrhea

questions.text: A Forensic Examiner receives the following skull of a victim of mob violence. Which of the following conclusions he makes is correct:

choices.text: The victim could have suffered a blunt force trauma
It is not possible to determine the sequence of injuries from fracture pattern
The victim could only have suffered from a gun-shot wound as indicated by Puppe’s rule
Fracture pattern in skull injuries are random and offer no clue upon examination

questions.solution:
Puppe’s Rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, and it is of particular importance in gunshot wounds. But the rule is not limited to gunshots.

Puppe’s rule: It is possible to determine the sequence of injuries in skull fractures caused by blunt injuries to the head because the second fracture ends at the point where a break in cohesion is already present. A new fracture Line does not cross an existing fracture line which can be used to determine the sequence of injuries.

Ex:- Correct sequence of shots in this would be 1->2->3

Note - Puppe's rule applies to any multiple blunt force trauma causing skull fractures.

questions.text: The presence of the following organism in the viscera of a person is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a diatom. The presence of diatoms in the viscera is suggestive of antemortem drowning because only a living person can transport diatoms from lungs to the viscera via circulation.

As the diatoms are found in both sea water and fresh water, their presence cannot differentiate between fresh water and sea water drowning.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

       Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Foam/froth at nostrils or mouth Not present
Cadaveric spasm Not present
Lungs usually are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated ,called as emphysema aquosum. Passive collection of water  in the lungs without any formation of columns of froth,has been called as oedema aquosum.
Presence of foam, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc. in the bronchi and bronchioles. Foreign matter may passively find access only to the upper respiratory passage.
Demonstration of diatoms in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc. Diatoms may reach the lungs but not to the distant organs because of absence of circulation.
Stomach may contain water and foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc which may be swallowed while struggling for life. Water could enter the stomach. However, quantity of foreign matter may become the decisive issue.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male had undergone resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of which of the following hormones is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Serum levels of gastrin is most likely to be reduced  in a patient who has undergone resection of gastric antrum.

Gastrin is secreted by the G cells in the gastric antrum. Gastrin has two main actions:

  • Stimulates secretion of H+ by gastric parietal cells
  • Promotes growth of the gastric mucosa (trophic action)

Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was being administered hydrocortisone for the treatment of autoimmune disease. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone may cause elevation of the plasma protein levels. All other options are incorrect.

Effects of cortisol/hydrocortisone:

On carbohydrate metabolism:

  • Increases gluconeogenesis
  • Decreases utilization of glucose by the cells.
  • Elevates blood glucose (option d)concentration.
  • Increases insulin secretion (option a).

On protein metabolism:

  • Causes decreased protein synthesis and increased catabolism of cellular proteins, especially in the extrahepatic tissues such as muscles and lymphoid tissue.
  • This leads to decreased muscle mass, and muscle weakness (patient may not be able to rise from a squatting position). 
  • Enhances amino acid transport into the liver, leading to increased liver proteins. As a result, there is increased production of plasma proteins in the liver, which are then released into the blood (option c).

On Fat metabolism:

  • Promotes mobilisation of fatty acids from the adipose tissue
  • Increases oxidation of fatty acids.
  • There may be deposition of fat in the chest and head regions of the body, giving a buffalo-like torso and a rounded moon face appearance.

High plasma levels of hydrocortisone, causes suppression of CRH and, consequently, reduces ACTH secretion (option b).

questions.text: A patient presents with loss of hemifacial sweating following removal of a retro-eosophageal goitre. All of the following are seen in this condition except:
questions.solution:
The Cervical sympathetic trunk is at risk of injury in invasive thyroid cancers and retro-esophageal goitres and may result in horners syndrome. 

Enophthalmos (sunken globe) is seen in Bernard-Horner’s syndrome and not exophthalmos.

Any condition or injury that destroys the sympathetic trunk ascending from the thorax through the neck into the face results in Horner’s syndrome.

Horner’s syndrome is characterized by

  • Ptosis
  • Miosis
  • Enophthalmos
  • Anhidrosis

Special features of congenital Horner’s syndrome are:

  • Iris heterochromia (due to lack of sympathetic stimulation during development)
  • Unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia. His peripheral blood smear shows the following characteristic of tumour cells. The tumour cells were found to be Annexin A1 positive. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.

Hairy cell leukemia:

  • Associated with BRAF mutations
  • Express the B-cell markers CD20; CD11c, CD103, and Annexin A1.
  • Occurs mainly in older males
  • Splenomegaly is the most common physical finding
  • Pancytopenia results from marrow infiltration and splenic sequestration
  • Hairy cells can be identified in the peripheral blood smear
  • Dry tap on aspirate.
  • Trephine biopsy: leukemic cells have a nucleus surrounded by cytoplasmic halo called as fried-egg appearance
  • Stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)
  • Extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents
  • Overall prognosis is excellent

questions.text: A 1 year and 1 month old child presented with developmental delay with her peripheral smear showing macrocytic anaemia. There is no B12 or folic acid deficiency. The compound given in the picture is excreted in the urine. Her peripheral smear is also given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is orotic aciduria.

Points in favour of orotic aciduria in the case above:

  • Developmental delay
  • Megaloblastic anemia, peripheral smear – hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Absence of B12 and folic acid deficiency
  • The compound given in the picture is Orotic acid which is excreted in urine.

Orotic aciduria: It is a rare autosomal recessive condition, involving error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines.

  • Type I: Deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl tranferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase).
  • Type II: Deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Confirmation of diagnosis requires assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patients erythrocytes. Anemia responds promptly to administration of uridine.

questions.text: Prosopagnosia is

choices.text: Inability to identify parts of the body

questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces

  • Autotopagnosia -  inability to recognize or to orient any part of one's own body
  • Simultagnosia - inability to recognize multiple elements in a visual presentation, one object or some elements of a scene can be appreciated but not the display as a whole
  • Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one’s own or another’s body
  • Tactile agnosia (aka stereognosia) -  inability to recognize objects by touch, in the presence of intact cutaneous and proprioceptive hand sensation; caused by a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was admitted with failure to thrive. Laboratory tests showed hypoglycemia and high glutamine and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated. The child became comatose and then parenteral dextrose was given. The child recovered from coma within 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the diagnosis is hyperammonemia type 2, which is due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine.

High glutamine: Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated.

Hypoglycemia: Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in blood.

Treatment:

Limiting intake of ammonia and increasing its excretion. Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.

Addition of Phenylbutyrate which scavenges nitrogen by combining with amino acids to form a more water-soluble product, which can be easily excreted by the kidneys.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to _____
questions.solution:
The given egg is of Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura).

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

Whipworms live in the large intestine and whipworm eggs are passed in the feces of infected persons. If the infected person defecates outside (near bushes, in a garden, or field) or if human feces are used as fertilizer, eggs are deposited on soil. They can then mature into an infective form.

Related Pearl: Mnemonic: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile stained eggs.

Mnemonic: FaT CAT

  • Fasciola hepatica (Sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (Giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke, Oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (Pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (Beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Mnemonic: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in saturated salt solution.

Mnemonic: THE FAN

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides

  • Necator americanus

questions.text: Muscle attached to the area marked in the diagram below:
questions.solution:
The image above shows the radius, identified by the radial head at the elbow joint. The arrow points to a raised area, which is the Radial Tuberosity.

Biceps Brachii is attached to radial tuberosity.

Biceps Brachii

Origin:

  • Short head arises from the apex of the coracoid process
  • Long head arises from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula

Insertion:

  • The two tendons end in a flattened tendon and attached to the radial tuberosity. 

Nerve supply:

  • Musculocutaneous Nerve (C5, C6)

questions.text: The most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is _________.
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the HMP pathway/pentose phosphate pathway.

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine was introduced in Intensified Mission Indradhanush?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus vaccine was introduced in Intensified Mission Indradhanush.

It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 

4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month. The diseases are

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertusis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ice-lined refrigerators (ILR)?

choices.text: Smaller ILRs are given to PHCs and the larger ones to district vaccine stores
They have temperature zones for different vaccines
Kata thermometer is used to record temperature inside the ILR
Most ILRs are provided with baskets to store vaccines

questions.solution:
Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ice-lined refrigerator.

  • ILRs are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centers. They are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines.

    They have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like Cholera, Hep B, Rotavirus(liquid), etc. All vaccines are kept in the basket provided with ILR. vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE can be kept at the bottom of the basket while, DPT, TT, Hep B, IPV, and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in the upper part of the basket.

questions.text: The histological image of a brain tumor arising in a 60-year-old man is given below. IDH mutation status of this tumor is most likely to be _________

choices.text: IDH has no diagnostic role in these tumors

questions.solution:
The clinical history and histological image are suggestive of primary glioblastoma. Most cases of primary glioblastoma are of the IDH-wild type.

The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which is characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme). 

According to the WHO Classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:  

1. Glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype:

    • About 90% of cases
    • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
    • Over 55 years of age

2. Glioblastoma, IDH-mutant:

    • About 10% of cases
    • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
    • Arises in younger patients

3. Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed. 

World Brain Tumor Day is now celebrated annually on 8 June as a tribute to all brain tumour patients and their families. As per the NHP data, the majority of patients suffering from brain tumour die within 9-12 months and less than 3% survive more than 3 years. So, it is important to create awareness among the people about the brain tumour.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle is India in currently?
questions.solution:
Currently, India is in stage 3 i.e. Late expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

Demographic gift or demographic dividend is seen in stage 3 of the demographic cycle. It is a phenomenon that India is currently experiencing, in which there is a higher number of economically productive population (young adults and middle-aged adults) due to a higher birth rate in previous demographic phase (phase 2).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the alphabets mark the C cells in the section of the thyroid gland shown below?
questions.solution:
Alphabet B marks the C cells in the section of the thyroid gland.

The C-cells (or parafollicular cells) are present between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They secrete calcitonin.

The thyroid gland is covered by a fibrous capsule with septae dividing it into lobules. These lobules contain follicles lined by follicular cells. The shape of the follicular cells depends on the activity of the gland. They're squamous in the inactive state, cuboidal to columnar in the active state. The cavity of the follicle contains colloid which appears pink in H and E staining.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is present in skeletal muscles, but absent in a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But troponin is absent in smooth muscle and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.text: The following antigen is produced by all of the following pathogens except__________.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Superantigen. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of a T cells, irrespective of antigen specificy, i.e., they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocaspid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  • Fungal
    • Malassezia furfur

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male underwent tooth extraction for caries tooth. 3 days later he presents with a fever and swelling on the right side of his neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. He also complains of difficulty in moving his jaw. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is found to be displaced medially. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, would be parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone)

Other options:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • Vincent’s angina (trench mouth) is an acute necrotizing infection of the oral cavity and the oropharynx.

Related Pearl: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage during the disaster?
questions.solution:
• In triage, green is low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.
  • Red is a high priority or transfer; yellow is medium priority and black is dead or moribund patients.
  • Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention.
  • It is done at the site of the disaster.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Priority Type of patients
Red High Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer (Eg. massive hemorrhage, tension pneumothorax)
Yellow Medium Possible resuscitation or surgery in next 24 hours (Eg. Isolated simple fracture)
Green Low Ambulatory patients or minor illness (Eg. Isolated abrasions, contusions, sprains)
Black Least  Dead or moribund patients (Eg. massive head injuries, 95% third degree burns)

questions.text:
Choose the appropriate response considering the following image
  1. The device shown in the image is a Slit Lamp Biomicroscope.
  2. It can be used to visualise the anterior chamber of the eye.
  3. The device shown in the image is an Optical coherence Biomicroscope
  4. It can be used to visualise the posterior chamber of the eye.
  5. It can be used to visualise the Retina.

choices.text: Only a and e are correct
Only c and e are correct
a, b and d are correct
b, c and d are correct

questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a Slit Lamp Biomicroscope.

  • It can be used to visualise the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye. It cannot be used to visualise the retina directly, because of the refractive power of ocular media.
  • Most slit-lamp microscopes offer magnifications between ×5 and ×50, with ×10, ×16, and ×25 being the most popular. Image resolution is ultimately limited by diffraction.
  • Because the cornea has such a high refractive power, the slit-lamp microscope can view only the first one-third of the eye. Special lenses, in conjunction with the slit-lamp microscope, can be used to view the posterior vitreous and the posterior pole retina.

questions.text: In a patient with urethral syndrome, urine microscopy shows full of polymorph, but no bacteria. The most appropriate culture medium is_____.
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of Chlamydial infection hence the most appropriate culture medium is McCoy cells(human synovial carcinoma cell line).

Abnormal urethral Gram’s stains showing >10 PMNs/1000Å~ field in women with dysuria but without coliform bacteriuria support the diagnosis of chlamydial urethritis.

Although Gonorrhea which grows on Thayer -Martin media causes urethral syndrome, Gonococci are typically found within polymorphs which is not seen in this case,hence ruled out.

Other options:

  • Thayer–Martin agar: Neisseria 
  • Robertson’s cooked meat: Anaerobes, especially Clostridia
  • Pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) broth: Mycoplasma spp. and Ureaplasma spp.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids has an imino ring?
questions.solution:
Proline is an amino acid with an imino ring.

The distinctive cyclic structure of the side chain of proline gives it exceptional conformational rigidity as compared to other amino acids; hence, proline plays a major role in collagen stability.

Tyrosine, Tryptophan and Phenylalanine do not contain an imino ring.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of pain in the left knee, which is tender on palpation. X-ray shows a 5 cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis, with "soap bubble" appearance. Microscopy is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is osteoclastoma/giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone.

  • GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s.
  • The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL, which promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.
  • GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis.
  • The majority arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia).
  • Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal extremities.
  • The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue.
  • Sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.
  • Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally.
  • Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are seldom fatal.
  • The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in GCT.

 

Remember E mnemonic for GCT-

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Egg-shell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: A woman became pregnant after 1 month of taking MMR vaccine, although she was advised to avoid pregnancy. What advice should the doctor give to the patient?

choices.text: Low risk; termination of pregnancy may be considered
High risk of anomalies; serious consideration for termination

questions.solution:
In this case scenario, the doctor should advise the patient to wait and watch.

The vaccine should not be administered during pregnancy. If pregnancy occurs within 28 days of immunization, the patient should be counseled on the theoretical risks for the fetus. Studies of over 200 women who had been inadvertently immunized with rubella vaccine during pregnancy showed that none of their offspring developed congential rubella syndrome. Therefore, termination of pregnancy is probably not warranted.

questions.text: Color discrimination is diminished in which of the following type of cataract?
questions.solution:
Nuclear cataract reduces color discrimination significantly.

They are usually bilateral and patient notices the difference after one eye is operated. Progressive yellowing or browning of lens causes poor color discrimination towards the blue end of visible spectrum.

Related Pearl: Important symptoms and their occurrence in cataract

Symptom Condition
Monocular diplopia or polyopia Cortical cataract (Incipient stage)
Color shift Nuclear cataract
Index hypermetropia Cortical cataract
Loss of ability to see objects in bright sunlight, blinded by the light of oncoming headlamps when driving at night Posterior subcapsular cataract and Nuclear cataract
Second sight/ Myopic shift/ Index myopia Nuclear cataract
Fluctuating refractive error Diabetic cataract (due to fluctuating blood sugar levels)

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

  • Stage of lamellar separation
  • Stage of incipient cataract
    • Cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.
  • Immature senile cataract/ Intumescent cataract:
    • Lens is greyish white.
    • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible.
  • Mature cortical cataract
    • Mature senile cataract/ripe cataract
    • Opacification is complete
    • Lens is pearly white

Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquifies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with change in the position of the head.

The image below depicts a Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man developed nausea and jaundice over the past week. On physical examination, he has right upper quadrant tenderness; his sclerae are icteric. Laboratory studies show he has a hepatitis B viral infection. His serum AST level is 189 U/L and serum ALT level is 202 U/L. Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely shown here in his liver?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman bodies.

These are acidophil bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis.

Councilman bodies are seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.

Hepatocyte apoptosis is an active form of 'programmed cell death' resulting in 

  • Hepatocyte shrinkage
  • Nuclear chromatin condensation( pyknosis)
  • Fragmentation (Karyorrhexis )
  • Cellular fragmentation into acidophilic apoptotic bodies

These changes are a result of caspase cascades of apoptosis. Apoptotic Hepatocytes were first described by William Thomas Councilman, hence often referred to as 'Councilman bodies'.

In the more frequent settings in which apoptotic hepatocytes are seen (eg., chronic hepatitis) , the term acidophil bodies is used, due to their deeply eosinophilic staining characteristics.

questions.text: Serologic test results from a hepatitis patient reveal: anti-HBc positive with low titres of IgM, HBsAg positive, HBe Ag negative,  and anti-HBs negative. The correct interpretation of the patient’s status is

choices.text: Hepatitis B virus chronic carrier state

questions.solution:
The serological test of this patient indicates chronic carrier state of hepatitis B.

HbsAg is positive only when the patient has acute infection or a chronic carrier and cannot be seen during window period.

Replicative activity (infectivity) is determined with level of HBeAg or HBV DNA.

Anti HbsAg is positive only during recovery or after vaccination.

Note: In contrast to the high titers of IgM-specific anti- HBc observed in acute disease, low titers of IgM anti-HBc are found in the sera of most chronic HBsAg carriers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been tested positive for SARS-COV-2. His household contacts are screened for the same, despite the absence of symptoms. What is the level of prevention employed here?
questions.solution:
Screening is a type of secondary prevention.

It is done to detect the disease in its early stages before it becomes clinically apparent.

Vaccination is the major primary prevention strategy in COVID 19.

Tertiary prevention measures in COVID 19 as in other conditions aims to treat and rehabilitate those having clinical disease and to reduce the complications or sequelae associated with this condition.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

questions.text: The image depicts
questions.solution:
Image shows Cottle test where cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly.
If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates abnormality of the vestibular component of nasal valve.
Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in treatment of BPPV.
Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is followed in accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.
Option D: Trotter’s method is used in treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.solution:

questions.text: The function of malachite green used in Lowenstein-Jensen media is to:
questions.solution:
Malachite green is the selective dye present in the LJ medium to prevent the growth of contaminants.

The selective media for Mycobacterium tuberculosis is Lowenstein–Jensen medium (LJ) medium.

Contents of LJ medium:

  • Malachite green (Prevents growth of contaminants)
  • Egg (provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism of mycobacteria).
  • Mineral salt solution (acts as a buffer)
  • Glycerol (Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis).
  • L-asparagine (Source of Nitrogen)

questions.text: All of the following are Integrin molecules except _____________.
questions.solution:
CD 31 or platelet endothelial cell-adhesion molecule 1 (PECAM-1) is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily expressed on endothelial cells, platelets, and some leukocytes.

These adhesion molecules, present in the inter­cellular junctions between endothelial cells, are involved in the migration of leukocytes.

The others, namely, LFA-1, MAC-1, and VLA-4, are integrins.

Adhesion molecules:

  • Selectins: Initial rolling interactions between leukocytes and endothelium
  • Integrins: Firm adhesion of leukocytes to endothelium
  • Immunoglobulin family:
    • PECAM (CD31): Most important adhesion molecule for diapedesis
    • ICAM-1: Binds to β2 integrins on leukocytes

questions.text: Tetrahydrobiopterin is a coenzyme for which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) is a coenzyme for the following enzymes:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase
  • Tyrosine hydroxylase
  • Tryptophan hydroxylase
  • Nitric oxide synthase

Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) resembles folic acid, but it is not a vitamin. It is derived from GTP.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism:
questions.solution:
• Hepcidin, ceruloplasmin, and transferrin are involved in iron metabolism.
  • Transthyretin transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein and has no role in iron metabolism

Proteins involved in iron metabolism:

  • Ferritin and hemosiderin: Iron storage
  • Transferrin: Iron transport
  • Ceruloplasmin: a copper-containing enzyme with ferroxidase activity
  • Hepcidin: Chief regulator of systemic iron homeostasis

questions.text: The type of speech seen in peritonsillar abscess is _______
questions.solution:
Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy. 

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. 

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat/ Dysphagia 
  • Drooling of saliva 
  • Trismus 
  • Ipsilateral otalgia 
  • Fever 

Management: Antibiotics and Incision & Drainage to drain the abscess followed by Interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding chalazion?
  1. Always Painful 
  2. Can occur in the upper or lower eyelid
  3. Hair follicle inflammation
  4. Meibomian Gland Inflammation
  5. Always treated with antibiotics
questions.solution:
The chalazion is the chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland. 

Chalazion (tarsal cyst/meibomian cyst)

  • Presents as a painless swelling of the eyelid
  • More common in adults than children
  • Treatment
    • Incision and curettage
    • Intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate

Sometimes, the chalazion may become secondarily infected and forms the hordeolum internum which is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct. It presents with a swelling similar to a chalazion, but more inflamed with pus pointing on the conjunctival surface. It can be treated conservatively with oral antibiotics and hot fomentation or with an incision and drainage.

An image of chalazion is shown below:

An image of hordeolum internum is shown below:

questions.text: 'How the differences in one variable can be explained by the differences in another variable' is analyzed by ______________
questions.solution:
The coefficient of determination expresses the proportion of variance in one variable that is explained by the variance in the other variable. The coefficient of determination is calculated by r2.

It gives the percentage variation in y explained by x-variables.

The range is 0 to 1 (i.e. 0% to 100% of the variation in y can be explained by the x-variables).

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Calculating one variable using another variable is done by the coefficient of regression.

The variation in one data set is compared with that of another data set by the coefficient of variation (CV). It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient, while its direction is indicated by the sign. The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below.

Examples:

Positive Correlation (+r): High salt intake is associated with high blood pressure.

Negative Correlation (-r): Increase in smoking of tobacco is associated with a decrease in life expectancy. 

No correlation (r=0): Height of a person and his blood group.

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson product-moment correlation
    It is used for data that have continuous intervals like salt intake vs BP to find a linear relationship.
  2. Spearman rank-order correlation
    It is used for data that have discrete ordered intervals like socioeconomic status vs parity to find a linear or non-linear relationship.

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable. For example - If a study finds a correlation (r) of 0.60 between smoking and life expectancy, it could be concluded that (0.6)2 = 0.36, or 36% of the variation in life expectancy in this study is accounted for by smoking.

Related Pearl: Regression

  • When two variables are very correlated, regression techniques are used to predict the value of one of the variables from the value of the other.
  • The value from which the other variable is calculated is called the independent variable and the variable for which the value is calculated is called the dependent variable.
  • Simple linear regression
    • In this, a mathematical equation called the regression equation is used to find the value of one variable (y) from another variable (x).
    • This equation quantifies the straight line relationship between two variables called the regression line.
    • It is given as, expected value of y = a + bx, where a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
    • The intercept constant is the point where the Y axis is intercepted by the regression line.
  • Multiple linear regression
    • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
    • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.
  • Logistic regression
    • In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease, etc.).
    • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly.
    • Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
    • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variables y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.
    • This is called logistic regression.

questions.text: Inhibitory effect on mucociliary clearance is minimal with?
questions.solution:
Both ipratropium and tiotropium have a minimal inhibitory effect on mucociliary clearance

Tiotropium is a long-acting muscarinic antagonist and Ipratropium is a short-acting muscarinic antagonist.

Tiotropium has a selective action on M1 and M3 receptors.

Tiotropium binds to all M1, M2 and M3 receptors. However, it dissociates slower from M1 and M3 receptors as compared to M2. This shows it has a higher affinity towards M1 and M3 receptors. 

Ipratropium and atropine methonitrate do not have any subtype selectivity on muscarinic receptors.

Clinical correlate

  • Inhibition of mucociliary clearance by atropine results in accumulation of lower airway secretions and formation of mucus plugs.
  • Tiotropium and ipratropium have minimum interference with mucociliary clearance and incidence of mucus plugs are less.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. Routine investigations and blood studies were normal. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?

The lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase results in excess glycogen build-up in muscles, as seen in the biopsy.

Features:

  • Abnormally high muscle glycogen (2.5-4%)
  • Very low blood lactate after exercise

questions.text: The COVID-19 outbreak is a type of ______________
questions.solution:
This outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a Propagated epidemic.

The propagated epidemic results from a person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. In this scenario, the cases of COVID occurred over a period which is more than one incubation period of the disease. Other examples of a propagated epidemic include Hepatitis A and Polio.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is single exposure from a point source.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposures epidemics:

  Point source, single exposure epidemic Point source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within a short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls within one incubation period of a particular disease Extends beyond one incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

 

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is neuroblastoma.

Most common cause:

Unilateral proptosis Bilateral proptosis
In children: Orbital cellulitis In children: Neuroblastoma and leukemia (chloroma)
In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy In adults: Thyroid ophthalmopathy

Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of cornea from the outer orbital margin (with the eyes looking straight ahead).

An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled as proptosis.

Instruments used to measure proptosis:

  • Luedde exophthalmometer
  • Hertel’s exophthalmometer: Most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures both eyes simultaneously.

Image: Bilateral proptosis

questions.text: To which of the following patients would you give 2 doses of rabies vaccine alone on day 0 and day 3?

choices.text: A 45 yr old unimmunized veterinarian who got a laceration by dog bite
A 23 yr old vaccinated woman who fed a stray dog which did not bite her
A 10 yr old vaccinated boy whose dog nibbled his toe but there was no bleeding
A 56 yr old unimmunized man whose dog licked his hand over intact skin

questions.solution:
This boy is a category II patient and treatment for him warrants wound management and rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3 (since the time of immunization is not mentioned).

Other options:

Options B and D: Are category I and do not require rabies prophylaxis.

Option A: Is category III and requires wound care, rabies immunoglobulin, and rabies vaccine.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins (WHO guidelines)

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, GOI:

Individuals with WHO category II or III exposures should receive PEP without delay.

One ID dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one IM dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • RIG provides a passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight.
  • WHO has recommended the use of Monoclonal Antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against RABV, as alternatives for RIGs in PEP.
  • All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration. Rabies immunoglobulin may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.
  • Prioritization of RIG allocation: Multiple bites>Deep wounds>Bites to head, neck, and hands>Patients with severe immunodeficiency>The biting animal is confirmed or probable rabies>Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

(PrEP)Pre-exposure prophylaxis

  • PrEP considered in remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult, the dog bite incidence is >5% per year or vampire bat rabies are known to be present.
  • Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of three intramuscular (IM) or intradermal (ID) doses are given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. For adults, the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm; for young children (under 1 year of age), the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended. Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.
  • For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous complete PrEP or PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:
    • Proper wound management should be done.
    • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
    • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.
    Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP or PrEP within the last three months.
    • People who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccine of unproven potency or cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment should be treated as a fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.text: A 35 yr old man presents with headache. On examination, his blood pressure is elevated. He has coarse facial features and frontal bossing, large hands and feet, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and a large fleshy nose. His age-matched serum IGF-I levels are elevated. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of acromegaly and is due to excess growth hormone (GH).

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism.

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumour. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analogue), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists, or radiation.

Other options:

Option B: Growth Hormone (GH) deficiency can lead to short stature and delayed growth in children, and reduced muscle mass, fatigue, and osteoporosis in adults. It may result from genetic factors, pituitary disorders, or brain injuries.

Option C: Excess somatostatin can inhibit growth hormone, insulin, and gastrin, causing symptoms like diabetes, gallstones, and digestive issues. It is often seen in somatostatinomas and rare pancreatic or duodenal tumours.

Option D: Deficiency of somatostatin can lead to excess secretion of growth hormone, insulin, and gastrin, potentially causing acromegaly, hyperinsulinemia, and peptic ulcers. This imbalance can result in uncontrolled hormone activity and digestive disturbances.

questions.text: A 70 year old woman comes to clinic with complaints of blurry vision. On assessment, vitals are normal. Visual acuity is 6/20 and intraocular pressure was elevated on both eyes.  Patient was prescribed topical Latanoprost which primarily acts by ______.
questions.solution:
Prostaglandin analogues act by increasing uveoscleral outflow. e.g., latanoprost, bimatoprost, travoprost. However, bimatoprost increases both outflows.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: Drug used to perform stress echo is
questions.solution:
Dobutamine is used to perform a stress test. They increase heart rate, thereby increase cardiac stress.

Dobutamine can be preferred over vasodilators for assessment of regional wall motion.

Vasodilators that can be used in stress echo 

  • Adenosine 
  • Dipyridamole 
  • Regadenoson - adenosine derivative; more selective A2A receptor agonist

questions.text: The microscopic finding as shown in the hair strand image is due to the deficiency of which of the following enzyme?
questions.solution:
Microscopic analysis of the hair shaft showing trichorrhexis nodosa and longitudinal breaks and is seen in Argininosuccinic aciduria due to the defect in the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

It is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily.

Trichorrhexis nodosa can also be caused by other disorders such as:

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Iron deficiency
  • Menkes' kinky hair syndrome

questions.text: According to IMNCI, it is classified as pneumonia if an 18 month old child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than:
questions.solution:
An 18 month old child presenting with a respiratory rate of more than 40 is classified as pneumonia.

Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with cough or difficult breathing:

  • Respiratory rate:
    • Which distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not
    • > 50 for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40 for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing
    • Which indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor
    • Which indicates those with severe pneumonia who require hospital admission.

The recent WHO guidelines states that chest indrawing and fast breathing is in category of pneumonia. Signs of severe pneumonia are :

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: A 24-year-old lab personnel has been given an intradermal injection of 0.1ml PPD (5 Tuberculin units) over the forearm. The site is examined after 72 hrs as shown in the image below. The interpretation of the result is:

choices.text: Tuberculin Test negative, suggesting an active infection
Tuberculin Test positive, suggesting an active infection
Tuberculin Test negative, suggesting a recent or past infection
Tuberculin Test positive, suggesting a recent or past infection

questions.solution:
The above image shows an induration of >10 mm after 72 hrs of intradermal PPD injection in a lab personnel suggesting a positive tuberculin test, indicating recent or past infection. 

Tuberculin Test:

Here, 0.1 ml of PPD (Purified protein derivative) containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally and induration is read after 48-72 hours. An induration of 10 mm or more is considered positive in patients from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. Surrounding erythema is not considered. 

A positive tuberculin test indicates hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein, denoting latent infection with tubercle bacilli or BCG immunization, recent or past infection with or without clinical disease. 

False positives may be seen in infections with related mycobacteria and false negatives in miliary tuberculosis, severely immunosuppressed states, etc. 

Related Pearl: Tuberculin reaction size & candidates for treatment of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection

HIV infected persons ≥5 mm
Recent contacts of a patient with TB ≥5 mm
Organ transplant recipients ≥5 mm
Persons with fibrotic lesions consistent with old TB on chest radiography ≥5 mm
Immunosuppressed persons ≥5 mm
Persons with high risk medical conditions (silicosis & end stage renal disease) ≥5 mm
Injection drug users ≥10 mm
Mycobacteriology lab personnel ≥10 mm
Children <5 years of age ≥10 mm
Recent immigrants from high prevalence countries

≥10 mm
Low-risk persons

           ≥15 mm

 

Tuberculin reactions are read at 48-72 hr as the transverse diameter of the induration, and the diameter of the erythema is NOT considered.

questions.text: In a primary health center, a nurse asks you about using a polio vaccine vial which has not crossed its expiry date. You look at the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) and tell her that it can be used. What did the VVM most likely show?

choices.text: Inner square white, outer circle blue
Inner square blue, outer circle white
Outer square white, inner circle blue
Outer square blue, inner circle white

questions.solution:
The standard polio vaccine vial monitor has an inner square and outer circle. It can be used if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.solution: The given image shows superficial fern like erythema called Arborescent or Filigree burns or Lichtenberg's flowers resembling branches of a tree which is characteristic of lightning stroke injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the muscle marked in red ?
questions.solution:
Longus colli (muscle in red) is situated on the anterior surface of vertebral column, between the atlas and third thoracic vertebra. The muscle is broad in the middle, narrow and pointed at either end, and consists of three portions - a superior oblique, inferior oblique and vertical.

Origin: Transverse process of C-5 to T-3

Insertion: Anterior arch of the atlas

Artery: Ascending pharyngeal, inferior thyroid and vertebral arteries

Nerve supply: C2 - C6 (anterior rami)

Actions: Flexes the neck forwards. Its main antagonist is longissimus cervicis.

questions.text: A patient presented with a swelling in his right foot with multiple discharging sinuses that contained brown granules. The lesion did not respond to antibiotic medications. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The history of multiple discharging sinuses that contained brown granules and the non-responsiveness to the antibiotics are suggestive of Eumycetoma. The causative agent of this is Madurella mycetomatis.

Actinomadura and Nocardia cause actinomycetoma which would respond to antibiotics.

  • Actinomycetoma

Involvement of bone is earlier and extensive

Wide (2–5mm) and septate hyphae, Periodic Schiff (PAS) positive and gram-negative easily visualized at ×400

Slender (0.5–1mm) and nonseptate, PAS negative and gram-positive filaments difficult to visualize even at ×800

Response to treatment

Unresponsive and requires surgical debulking

Good response

questions.text: You are a medical practitioner in a remote rural area, you remove a worm from a patient as shown below by rolling it over a stick. The worm that you are removing by this procedure is ____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the way Guinea worm(Dracunculiasis) is removed by rolling them out over a small stick.

Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinenesis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

The life cycle of Guinea worm:

Guinea-worm disease is amenable to eradication. 

  • Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.
  • Wet compresses may relieve discomfort. Occlusive dressings improve hygiene and limit shedding of infectious larvae.
  • No drug cures the infection but metronidazole and mebendazole are sometimes used to limit inflammation and facilitate worm removal.
    • Provision of safe drinking water (e.g., piped water, installation of hand pumps).
    • Control of cyclops
  • Health education of the public in matters relating to boiling or sieving drinking water through a double thickness cotton cloth for personal protection, and prevention of water contamination by infected persons.
  • Surveillance: Active search for new cases.

questions.text: Mrs. 'A' is a 26 yr old woman who is in her second trimester. She is a sedentary worker. Her colleague,Mrs 'B' has delivered a baby boy 3 months ago, and she is breastfeeding the baby. How much should Mrs 'A' and 'B'  increase in their caloric intake per day, respectively?
questions.solution:
Mrs. 'A' who is in her second trimester should increase her calorie intake by 350 calories/day, and her colleague who is breastfeeding her 3-month-old baby should increase her calorie intake 600 calories/day.

The addition of 350 kcal/day is recommended during pregnancy. During the first six months of lactation, an increase of 600 calories is recommended, and from 6-12 months of lactation, 520 extra calories are recommended.

questions.text: The space of Disse consists of all of the following except ______
questions.solution:
Kupffer cells are present in the lining of the walls of the sinusoids, not in the Space of Disse (perisinusoidal space). 

Kupffer cells arealso known as stellate macrophages or Kupffer-Browicz cells. They are specialized macrophages present in the liver and are part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

The perisinusoidal space (or space of Disse) is the area between hepatocyte and a sinusoid. Microvilli of hepatocytes extend into this space, allowing proteins and other plasma components from the sinusoids to be absorbed by the hepatocytes.

Contents of this space are as follows:

  • Interstitial fluid
  • Microvilli of adjacent hepatocytes
  • Hepatic stellate cells (Ito cells)
  • Fine collagen fibers (mostly type III)
  • Fat cells

Lymph produced in the liver drains via the perisinusoidal space of Disse and periportal clefts of Mall to larger lymphatics.

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student received booster dose of Hepatitis B vaccination, following which she developed weakness in the abduction and lateral rotation of that arm. The lesion is most likely to be in which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve also called a Surgeon's nerve is frequently injured during inadvertent intramuscular (IM) injections. 

Named nerves of the upper limb:

  • Laborer’s nerve: Median nerve.
  • Musician’s nerve: Ulnar nerve.
  • Surgeon’s nerve: Axillary nerve.
  • Nerve of Bell: Long thoracic nerve.

Course of Axillary nerve:

  • Origin -  Posterior cord of brachial plexus in the axilla. 
  • In Axilla - Exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm.
  • In Arm - Winds around the surgical neck of the humerus and gives cutaneous supply to the lower part of deltoid "upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm".

Axillary nerve Injury: 

Injury mostly is due to fracture of surgical neck of humerus, inferior dislocation of humerus and inadvertent IM injection.

Test: Loss of sensation over the skin of the lower part of the deltoid muscle (regimental badge anesthesia) in case of lesion of the nerve.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman required a blood transfusion following a post-partum hemorrhage. Her relative volunteered to donate the blood. The agglutination test of the donor's blood is as shown below. The donor's blood can be transfused if the patient has any of the following blood groups except:
questions.solution:
Based on the agglutination test, the donor's blood group is O positive. Therefore, it can be administered to a patient of any blood group, except to females in reproductive age group, with Rh-negative blood group.

Among the given options, only option d is Rh-negative. Transfusion of O positive (donor's blood) to O negative (recipient's blood), may cause sensitization leading to a risk of hemolytic disease of the newborn in subsequent pregnancies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the structure indicated by the white arrow in the given image?

choices.text: It forms the base of the sylvian cistern
It lies between the frontal and temporal lobe
It receives somatosensory inputs from the entire body

questions.solution:
The structure marked by the arrow is the insular lobe. The insular cortex is not entirely agranular. The posterior part of the insular cortex is granular and the anterior part is agranular.

The insula forms the base of the sylvian cistern and lies between the frontal and temporal lobes. It receives somatosensory, viscerosensory, homeostatic, and nociceptive information from the entire body. It receives inputs from the thalamus.

questions.text: A child presents alone to your OPD and is seeking treatment for a minor medical condition for which you need to do a general physical examination. You can perform an examination with just the child’s consent if the child is older than at least ________
questions.solution:
The minimum age for giving a valid consent for general/physical examination is 12 years. For a child, less than 12 years of age, consent should be obtained from the parent/guardian.

questions.text: Which of the following measures is not advocated for controlling the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis?

choices.text: The use of indoor residual sprays
Keeping pigs away from human dwellings
The use of Malathion for outdoor fogging

questions.solution:
Indoor residual sprays are not used in the vector control measures for Japanese Encephalitis, as its vectors are outdoor resters.

Japanese encephalitis is caused by group B arbovirus (Flavivirus) and transmitted by culex mosquitoes.

Prevention and control of JE:

  • Vaccination: SA-14-14-2 strain is used in India. A single dose is given followed by a single booster given at an interval of about 1 year. The children between 1 - 15 years of age are immunized.
  • Keeping pigs away from human dwellings from dusk to dawn (biting time of the vectors). Pigs act as important amplifiers of the virus.
  • Use of bed nets for personal protection.
  • Use of larvivorous fishes.
  • Using Malathion for outdoor fogging to control an outbreak.

 

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

questions.text: A newborn on examination was found to have deafness, cataract and ventricular septal defect. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing this syndrome?

choices.text: Both postnatally and congenitally acquired infection can become carriers
The infected person can transmit infection from one week before the onset of rashes
It has one of the most effective vaccine available as seroconversion is more than 95%

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is classic for congenital rubella syndrome (deafness, cataract, and cardiac defects).

Only congenitally acquired infection can turn into a carrier state.

Other options are correct.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss: Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease: The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis: Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months. 

Image: Bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

 

Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient with diabetic neuropathy, on examination, was found to have a loss of sensation to tap and vibration at low frequency (20 Hz), but an intact vibration sense at a higher frequency (200 Hz). Which of the following somatosensory receptors is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Sensations of tap and low-frequency vibration (flutter, 5-40 Hz) are sensed by the Meissner's corpuscles. Hence, a loss of sensation of tap and flutter is most likely due to the disease affecting the Meissner's corpuscles.

 

Cutaneous mechanoreceptors: There are four types of mechanoreceptors for sensing touch and pressure. They include:

  • Meissner corpuscles
  • Merkel cells
  • Ruffini corpuscles
  • Pacinian corpuscles

 

Meissner corpuscles are dendrites encapsulated in the connective tissue beneath the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to tap and flutter (low-frequency vibration - 5-40Hz).

 

Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to sustained pressure and touch.

 

Ruffini's corpuscles are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They respond to stretch and fluttering vibration.

 

Pacinian corpuscles:

  • They are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptor, measuring about 2mm in length and 1mm in diameter.
  • They are present in the dermis of glabrous (non-hairy) and hairy skin.
  • A Pacinian corpuscle consists of a nerve ending encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving it an onion-like appearance.
  • They respond to fast vibration (60-500Hz) and deep pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is based on the principle that prior knowledge of the events/activity will influence the suspect’s reaction?
questions.solution:
Brain Mapping is based on the principle that if the suspect has prior knowledge of the event/activity being described it will reflect in the suspect’s brain wave responses.

It is a technique that measures recognition of familiar stimuli by measuring electrical brain wave responses(P300) to words, phrases, or pictures that are presented on a computer screen.

Truth serum : This is based on the principle, that at a point very close to unconsciousness, the subject will be mentally incapable of resisting questioning and will be incapable of lying.

Polygraph : It is based on the theory, that when a person lies in the answer to a question, if he/she experiences fear, the emotion of fear will result in certain physiological changes.

The physiological changes are commonly observed are :

  1. Relative rise in blood pressure
  2. Pulse rate increases
  3. Slowing down of breathing/erratic breathing
  4. Suppression of involuntary muscular movements
  5. Increased activity of sweat glands
