questions.text: A registered medical practitioner is requested by a survivor of sexual violence to examine her. What is the maximum time by which the practitioner can take a vaginal swab to look for the presence of spermatozoa?
questions.solution:
A vaginal swab of a rape victim demonstrates spermatozoa if the vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours after an assault.

However vaginal swab can be taken within 96 hours to demonstrate semen.

Evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing can be collected even after 96 hours.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man complains of difficulty in micturition and a thin urine stream. On digital examination of the rectum, moderate uniform enlargement of the prostate is appreciated. Patient was given Tamsulosin and Finasteride. Finasteride acts by blocking_____?
questions.solution:
Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of 5 α-reductase enzyme. It is more selective to type 2 enzyme whereas dutasteride inhibits both type 1 and type 2 enzyme. It blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

Uses:

  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia 
  • Male pattern baldness (effective although type 1 enzyme appears to be predominantly involved)
  • Hirsutism

The first-line therapy for Benign prostatic hyperplasia is alpha-blockers. Combination therapy with an alpha-blocker and 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor has been shown to have increased efficacy.

Related Pearl: Benign prostatic hyperplasia treatment

  • Static component: 5 alpha-reductase inhibitor [eg: Finasteride]
  • Dynamic component: Alpha 1 blockers [eg: Tamsulosin, terazosin etc]

questions.text: A 40 year old woman came with complaints of bleeding from the gums for the past 1 hour. She has history of similar episodes on and off from her childhood. On investigation, the platelet  Count is normal, but the bleeding time and aPTT are increased. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is ' Von Willebrand disease'. It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder of humans. The most common presenting symptoms are spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes ( eg., epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds or menorrhagia. 

Type 1 and type 3 von Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor (vWF). Type 2 vWD is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF; there are several subtypes, of which type 2A is the most common. In Type 2, vWF is expressed in normal amounts, but missense mutations are present that lead to defective multimer assembly.

Type 3 is associated with very low levels of vWF and correspondingly severe clinical manifestations.

Laboratory findings in vWD:

  • Prolonged bleeding time in the presence of a normal platelet count.
  • The defective platelet adhesion also results in a positive tourniquet test (Hess test).
  • Ristocetin-induced aggregation is defective and is diagnostic of this disease. However, platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and thrombin is normal.
  • Though the synthesis of factor VIII remains normal, the half-life of VIII in plasma decreases due to reduced vWF (carrier) levels. This leads to secondary VIIIC deficiency in plasma. So, the intrinsic pathway of coagulation is affected, and thus, aPTT is increased in these patients.
  • Prothrombin Time is also elevated.

Subtype

Description

Inheritance

Lab findings

Type 1

Quantitative deficiency of vWF

Autosomal dominant

Reduced vWF antigen, activity and Factor VIII

Type 2

Qualitative defect in vWF

Autosomal dominant

Reduced vWF activity to antigen ration<0.6

Type 3

Near-complete deficiency of Factor VIII

Autosomal recessive

Marked reduction or absence in Factor VIII levels

 TREATMENT:

Persons with type 1 or 2 Von Willebrand disease facing hemostatic challenges ( dental work, surgery) can be treated with desmopressin ( which stimulates vWF release) , infusions of plasma concentrates containing factor VIII and vWF or with recombinant vWF. 
Patients with type 3 disease must be treated prophylactically with plasma concentrates and factor VIII infusions to prevent severe 'haemophilia-like' bleeding.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals a child with sparse and kinky hair. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia. These features strongly suggest a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

This results from a deficiency of its co-factor i.e copper due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
  • ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Other options:

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD) enzyme defect causes Maple syrup urine disease (Option A)

Valine transaminase enzyme defect causes Hypervalinemia (Option B)

A defect in Cystathionine synthase causes Homocystinuria type I (Option D)

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: The ophthalmologic instrument shown in the image is not used for:
questions.solution:
The image shows a Stenopaic Slit. It is not used in Corneal Tattooing.

It can be used to: 

  • Determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.
  • In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit
  • Perform Fincham's Test

questions.text: Identify the ophtalmological  instrument in the image:
questions.solution:
Corneal thickness is best measured by a pachymeter.

  • Measurement of the corneal thickness (pachymetry) indirectly reflects endothelial function.
  • The average central corneal thickness is around 0.5 mm, which gradually increases toward the periphery to around 0.7 mm.
  • Normally, as a diurnal variation, corneas tend to be slightly thicker just after a person awakes in the morning.

 Image: Corneal pachymeter

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from ________
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. Liver microscopy shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The characteristic triad of hemochromatosis includes:

  1. Micronodular cirrhosis
  2. Diabetes mellitus in 75% to 80% of patients
  3. Abnormal skin pigmentation in 75% to 80% of patients

Note: The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presented with lethargy and myxedema. Her TSH levels are low. However, after administration of TRH, the TSH levels have increased. Which of the following conditions is most likely possible?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to abnormality in pituitary gland
Hypothyroidism due to abnormality in pituitary gland
Hyperthyroidism due to abnormality in hypothalamus
Hypothyroidism due to abnormality in hypothalamus

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of hypothyroidism due to abnormality in the hypothalamus.

Thyroid function is controlled by the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH, thyrotropin), which is secreted by the anterior lobe of the pituitary. The secretion of this hormone is stimulated by thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. TSH secretion is also subject to negative feedback control by high circulating levels of thyroid hormones acting on the anterior pituitary and the hypothalamus.

Lethargy and myxedema are clinical features seen in hypothyroidism. The TSH levels may be low either due to abnormality in the pituitary gland or hypothalamus.

However, the response of pituitary gland to the administration of TRH, indicates that the pituitary gland is normal. This suggests that the reduced levels of TSH in this patient are due to the reduced TRH production due to abnormality in the hypothalamus. TSH levels may not be elevated following a test dose of TRH, in rare cases, where there is a depressed response of pituitary gland to TRH.

Related Pearl: Causes of hypothyroidism:

 

Primary (Low T3, T4 > Raised TSH levels) Secondary (Low TSH levels > Low T3, T4) Tertiary ( Low TRH > Low TSH > Low T3,T4 )

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyrioditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: Orbital complications are most commonly seen following which sinus infection?
questions.solution: Orbit and its contents are closely related to the ethmoid, frontal and maxillary sinuses, but most of the complications, however, follow infection of ethmoids as they are separated from the orbit only by a thin lamina of bone— lamina papyracea.

questions.text: Individuals who had subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease are known as:
questions.solution:
Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease. However, they still shed the disease agent.

Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

All individuals with a subclinical infection are not considered as carriers. Only those, who disseminate or shed the disease agent are considered as carriers. For example, in polio, the infection may be subclinical, and the person may shed the virus, thus acting as a healthy carrier. In contrast, a patient with tuberculosis may have a subclinical infection but doesn't disseminate the tubercle bacilli. In such case, the individual with subclinical tuberculosis infection is not a carrier.

 

Other options:

Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection, who acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for polio virus.

Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. Which means, these carriers transmit the disease before the onset of the illness. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria and hepatitis B.

Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. This may occur in cases where the clinical recovery does not coincide with the bacteriological recovery, and the individual may continue to shed the disease agent. Examples: Typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amoebic), cholera, diphtheria and whooping cough.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented with complaints of intense irritation, pain and insects crawling in his right ear canal. On examination of right ear, a black ant was found crawling inside. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Kill the insect by instilling oil

questions.solution:
Flying or crawling insects like mosquitoes, beetles, cockroaches or ants may enter the ear canal and cause intense irritation and pain.

No attempt should be made to catch them alive. First, the insect should be killed by instilling oil (a household remedy), spirit or chloroform water. Once killed, the insect can be removed by any of the methods described below:

  • Forceps removal
  • Syringing
  • Suction
  • Microscopic removal with special instruments

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic with stomach pain. On examination, you notice the image below. Which of the following is not used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Kayser-Fleischer ring due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea which is seen in Wilsons disease

Calcium citrate is not used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

Treatment of Wilson's disease includes the administration of zinc which blocks the intestinal absorption of copper and sequester additional toxic copper. In patients with neurologic manifestations, tetrathiomolybdate is the preferred drug of choice as it preserves neurologic functions.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

questions.text: Milk alkali syndrome is characterized by ______.
questions.solution:
Milk alkali syndrome is characterized by :

  • Alkalosis
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Renal insufficiency

Milk alkali syndrome used to occur in patients who were administered high doses of NaHCO3 and CaCO3 along with milk or cream for the management of peptic ulcers. The syndrome is rare now and generally occurs with a large intake of calcium supplements along with milk.

questions.text: You are a newly posted factory medical officer and you observe that the factory doesn't have proper ventilation which is not good for its workers. After your suggestion, the factory officials deploy the use of centrifugal fans and exhaust fans for proper ventilation. This type of ventilation is called _______
questions.solution:
The mechanical system of ventilation which employs both plenum ventilation (centrifugal fans) and exhaust ventilation (exhaust fans), is called Balanced ventilation.

Types of ventilation:

  • Natural ventilation:
    • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
    • Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action.
    • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings
    • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through space by providing openings at appropriate places, like opposite to each other.
    • The drawback of natural ventilation is that the regulation of air quality is not possible.
  • Mechanical ventilation:
    • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans which run on electricity and are placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
    • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
    • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
    • Air conditioning is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odors and toxic gases.

questions.text: A patient has dry eye and reduced nasal secretions. The location of a lesion might be in the ____.
questions.solution:
In this patient with dry eye and reduced nasal secretions, the lacrimal gland, and glands of the nasal mucosa are affected. So the lesion is possibly in the sphenopalatine ganglion.

Parasympathetic (secretomotor) supply to the lacrimal gland, glands of the nasal mucosa and palate travel in the nerve of the pterygoid canal i.e, Vidian nerve, and reach the sphenopalatine ganglion (a.k.a Pterygopalatine ganglion or nasal ganglion) where they relay before reaching the target. They also supply the blood vessels of the nose and cause vasodilation.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text: How long is thyroxine stored in thyroid follicles?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine is stored in the thyroid follicles for 2-3 months, bound to thyroglobulin. 

When the synthesis of thyroid hormone ceases, the physiological effects of deficiency are not observed for several months.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum malaria. What treatment would she be started on?
questions.solution:
Falciparum malaria during the second and third trimester of pregnancy should be treated with ACT.

Treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy:

  • 1st trimester: Quinine
  • 2nd and 3rd trimester: ACT-AL in north eastern states and ACT-SP in other states.

Treatment of vivax malaria during pregnancy:

  • DOC: Chloroquine

Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to _________.
questions.solution:
Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to cefotetan, which is a second- generation cephalosporins. B. cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to a wide range of antimicrobial agents, including                  
 
-Aminoglycosides 

-Polymyxin,

-First- and second-generation cephalosporins, and

-Carboxypenicillins.

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include

  • Meropenem,
  • Ceftazidime,
  • Piperacillin,
  • Temocillin, and
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

questions.text: Which of the following tissue stem-cell locations is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The stem cells in the intestine are the cells interspersed between the paneth cells found near the base of the crypt.

The tissue stem cells, also called adult stem cells, are undifferentiated cells, found among differentiated cells in a tissue or organ.

These cells are capable of proliferation, self-renewal, and production of a large number of differentiated functional progeny involved in regenerating tissues after injury.

The tissue stem cells are normally protected within specialized tissue microenvironments called stem cell niches.

questions.text: Read the ECG. Pharmacological treatment of choice for the patient's condition is
questions.solution:
Image show above in the ECG shows Long QT Syndrome characterized by QT interval more than 450 ms in males and 470 ms in females

questions.text: A 28-year-old HIV patient presents with non-productive cough and difficulty in breathing which was progressively increasing. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with pneumatocele. Gomori’s methenamine silver staining of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows the following. The most probable causative organism is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the GMS stain showing the black colored stained cysts resembling the crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia. It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive.

Pneumocystis jirovecii causes pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm3 and usually presents with fever, dry cough, and dyspnea. Inspiratory crackles are heard on auscultation.

The most common finding on chest x-ray if the disease is suspected early is either a normal film or a faint bilateral interstitial infiltrate. The classic finding of a dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

The chest radiograph given below shows ground-glass opacities in PCP.

Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the clinic with visual disturbance. He has a history of erectile dysfunction and has been recently taking medication for it. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause visual disturbances by PDE6 inhibition?
questions.solution:
Visual disturbance due to PDE-6 inhibition is seen with sildenafil.

Sildenafil and Vardenafil cause retinal PDE-6 inhibition and can result in blurring of vision and blue-green tinting of the vision. 

Tadalafil and Avanafil have better PDE-5/PDE-6 selectivity, so their visual side effects are less. 

Note: PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates should not be prescribed together due to increase risk of hypotension.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to your OPD with double vision, hearing loss in left ear. On examination, you find left esotropia and facial palsy. Most likely location of the lesion is:
questions.solution:
Based on clinical history and examination, the CP angle is the most likely location of the lesion.

Compression of vestibulocochlear nerve and facial nerve causes hearing loss and facial palsy. Ophthalmic symptoms such as diplopia, blurred vision are related to the mass effect on adjacent cranial nerves.

Cavernous sinus pathology presents with involvement of cranial nerves 4,6,3 but doesn't involve cranial nerve 7 and 8.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common, and among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations

  • Perimetry: Initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Atypical types of RP are as follows:

  • Sectoral RP
  • Pericentric/Inverse RP
  • RP sine pigmento
  • RP punctata albescens

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: The cardiac jelly formed around the heart tube during early development, contributes to the formation of:
questions.solution:
The cardiac jelly is a gelatinous substance present between the endocardium and myocardium of the embryonic heart that transforms into the connective tissue of the endocardium.

Cardiac jelly:

  • The extracellular matrix of the heart or the cardiac jelly is secreted by myocardium.
  • It promotes occlusion of the endocardial tubular lumen during myocardial contraction.
  • It has been called a gelatinoreticulum, a myoepicardial reticulum and, more recently, the myocardial basement membrane.
  • It is composed of hyaluronic acid, hyaluronidase and fibronectin, among other things.

questions.text: The collagen defective in Alport’s syndrome is
questions.solution:
In Alport’s syndrome, there is a defect in Type IV collagen.

Type IV collagen is an important component in the basement membranes of renal glomeruli, inner ear, and eye. Hence, the main presenting feature of Alport’s syndrome is hematuria, accompanied by ocular lesions-anterior lenticonus and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with easy fatiguability and was diagnosed as iron deficiency anemia. She was advised to take oral iron supplements. Foods containing which of the following should not be taken along with her iron supplements?
questions.solution:
Absorption of iron is decreased by tannates found in tea.

Iron absorption is increased by ascorbic acid, citric acid, amino acids and sugars in the diet.

 It is decreased by phosphates, carbonates, oxalates, and tannates.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: A patient with long-standing corticosteroid use was admitted for rhinocerebral mucormycosis. Which of the following is seen on microscopic examination?

choices.text: Broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching
Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule

questions.solution:
Mucromycosis under microscope is seen as broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching.

It is an opportunistic fungal seen in patients with acidosis such as diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The most common agent is Rhizopus oryzae and common clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis where there is an invasion of the blood vessels in nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis.

Treatment: Surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration.

Other options:

  • Long conidiophores with terminal vesicles: Aspergillus
  • Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule: Cryptococcus neoformans
  • Oval, budding yeast cells: Candida

questions.text: The part marked "x" in the image given below consists of all except ______
questions.solution:
The part marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male suffered from a stroke in the medulla and pons, which led to complete obliteration of the vagal input to the oesophagus. Which of the following changes are likely to be seen?

choices.text: Elimination of primary oesophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of secondary oesophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of both primary and secondary oesophageal peristalsis
No change in  primary and secondary oesophageal peristalsis

questions.solution:
Absence of vagal input to the oesophagus will result in the elimination of only the primary peristalsis of oesophagus. The secondary peristalsis will remain intact due to the activity of intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus.

Oesophagal peristalsis: There are two types of oesophageal peristaltic movements: primary and secondary.

A. Primary peristalsis:

  • It occurs as a continuation of the peristaltic wave that begins in the pharynx and spreads into the oesophagus during the pharyngeal stage of swallowing.
  • It passes from the pharynx to oesophagus, within about 8 to 10 seconds.
  • However, due to the effect of gravity in an upright position, the food passes within 5 to 8 seconds.

B. Secondary peristalsis:

  • It occurs if the primary peristaltic wave failed to empty the food from the oesophagus into the stomach.
  • Secondary peristalsis is initiated by the distension of the oesophagal wall by the retained food.
  • Waves continue until all the food is emptied into the stomach.
  • Secondary peristaltic waves are initiated partly by intrinsic neural circuits in the myenteric nervous system and partly by reflexes that begin in the pharynx.
  • Pharyngeal reflexes are then transmitted upward through vagal afferent fibres to the medulla and back again to the oesophagus through glossopharyngeal and vagal efferent nerve fibres.

 

 

Control of peristaltic waves:

  • The musculature of the pharyngeal wall and upper third of the oesophagus is striated muscle. These regions are controlled by skeletal nerve impulses from the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.
  • The musculature of the lower two-thirds of the oesophagus is smooth muscle. This region is strongly controlled by the vagus nerves, which act through connections with the oesophagal myenteric nervous system.

 

Effect of obliteration of vagal input to the oesophagus:

  • When the vagal nerves are cut, or the vagal input is obliterated by any other cause such as stroke, the primary peristalsis, which is solely dependant on the vagal innervation, is eliminated.
  • However, the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus of the oesophagus becomes excitable, with a few days, which causes strong secondary peristaltic waves.
  • Therefore, even after paralysis of the brain stem swallowing reflex, food fed by a tube into the oesophagus passes into the stomach due to the secondary peristaltic movements.

questions.text: Which of the following is both a diffusion and dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Epsilometer method (E-test) is both a diffusion and dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity. It is a quantitative technique for determining the antimicrobial susceptibility (AST) and MIC (in µg/mL) of gram-negative and gram-positive aerobic bacteria.

The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:

  • Diffusion methods: Kirby–Bauer method, Stokes method
  • Dilution methods: Tube dilution, Agar dilution
  • Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)

questions.text: Which of the following does not form a boundary of the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
Ischial tuberosity does not form a boundary of the pelvic inlet.

Boundaries of the pelvic inlet:

  • Posterior: The sacral promontory
  • Lateral: The arcuate line on the inner surface of the ilium and the pectineal line on the superior ramus.
  • Anterior: The pubic symphysis

 Boundaries of the pelvic outlet:

  • Posterior: The tip of the coccyx
  • Lateral: The ischial tuberosities and the inferior margin of the sacrotuberous ligament
  • Anterior: The pubic arch

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines recruit neutrophils and monocytes?
questions.solution:
IL-17 recruits neutrophils and monocytes , which causes destruction of extra-cellular bacteria and fungi.

Cell-mediated immune response:

During the antigen recognition process, the cytokines stimulate the CD4+ naive T cells to differentiate into subsets of helper T (TH) cells, which include TH1, TH2, TH17 cells. Each of these cells secretes a different set of cytokines to perform various functions.

  • TH1 cells: They secrete IFN-γ which activates macrophages and stimulates the production of IgG antibodies. The CD40  and IFN-γ together play a role in the classical pathway of macrophage activation.
  • TH2 cells: They secrete IL-4, IL-5, IL-13.
    • IL-4 stimulates the B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.
    • IL-5 activates eosinophils. The eosinophils and mast cells bind to the IgE coated helminthic parasites and helps in their elimination.
    • IL-4 and IL-13 stimulate the alternative pathway of macrophage activation.
  • TH17 cells: They secrete IL-17, which recruits neutrophils and monocytes, which causes destruction of extracellular bacteria and fungi, and play a role in inflammatory diseases like IBD, psoriasis, MS.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Pro-inflammatory cytokines

  • IL-2  Induce proliferation and maturation of T cells
  • IL-6  B-cell stimulation, mediator of acute phase reactions
  • IL-8 
  • IFN-alpha  Antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity),
    antiproliferative
  • TNF-alpha  Activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase
    proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6
Anti-inflammatory cytokines
  • IL-4
  • IL-10  Inhibit IFN-γ and IL-12 production
  • IL-13
Acute inflammation and sepsis

  • IL-1
Granuloma formation

activation), antiproliferative

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of the case-control study except?
questions.solution:
Incidence of a disease cannot be calculated from a case-control study.

Advantages of case-control study:

  • Simple to conduct
  • Less time consuming
  • Less expensive
  • No problem in follow up/drop out (attrition)
  • Suitable for rare diseases
  • Multiple types of exposure causing a single disease can be studied
  • The odds ratio can be obtained

Disadvantages of case-control:

  • Bias is present- Either recall or selection bias
  • The temporality of association cannot be determined
  • The natural history of the disease cannot be studied
  • Incidence, relative risk, and attributable risk cannot be calculated

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occured but not disease.
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a Cohort Study
    • Types
      • Prospective cohort studies (concurrent cohort studies)
      • Retrospective cohort studies (historical cohort study)
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages and disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Incidence can be calculated.

Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at same time.

Provides direct estimate of relative risk

Calculation of dose-response ratio

Minimization of certain biases

Cannot be used for uncommon diseases

Uses a large population

Takes a long time to complete

Many common administrative problems

Attrition is high.

Selection of subjects is difficult.

Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate.

Tend to be expensive.

Tends to alter behaviour of subjects: Hawthorne effect.

Ethical problems

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids is a constituent of the human lung surfactant?
questions.solution:
Dipalmitoyl lecithin/Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is a major component of lung surfactant.

In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. 

Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus.

Clinical correlate :

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates is due to insufficient surfactant production.
  • Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.

Other options:

Diphosphatidyl glycerol, also called cardiolipin, is found in the inner membrane of mitochondria and plays a key role in apoptosis. (Option B)

Phosphatidylinositol present in the cell membrane acts as precursors of hormone secondary messengers and platelet-activating factor. (Option C)

Phosphatidylserine is a component of the cell membrane and plays a key role in cell cycle signaling, specifically in relation to apoptosis. (Option D)

 

Related Pearl: Pulmonary Surfactant Composition

Constituents

Percentage

Phospholipids, mainly dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)

70% to 80%

Proteins

10%

Neutral lipids

10%

questions.text: A 20 days old child is gasping for air and not feeding properly. The mother has no money to go the nearby hospital. Which National Programme has provisions to benefit this woman to take her to the health facility?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram has provisions of free transport from home to the health institutions, between facilities in case of referral and back home from the health institution. These provisions are for:

  • Pregnant women
  • Sick infants 

It includes:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

The LAQSHYA initiative is for improving the quality of labour rooms and providing Respectful Maternity Care. It also includes expanding the obstetric ICUs at government medical college hospitals.

The Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyaan (PMSMA) ensures quality antenatal care so that a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her 2nd or 3rd trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

The explanation of this MCQ is revised. Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborn till 30days after birth now it is expanded to cover infants also. 

Every year 28th May has been commemorated as the International Day of Action for Women’s Health, to create awareness regarding the sexual and reproductive health and rights of women worldwide.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses have the hematology findings given below?
questions.solution:
The findings present in the above hematology slide are basophilic stippling  (punctate basophilia) with Cabot’s ring . They are features seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism).

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma)
  • F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)

Other Options:

  • Minamata disease: Chronic mercury poisoning, can show anemia secondary to GI haemorrhage.
  • Chronic Iron Toxicity: in severe cases, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).
  • Arsenic Poisoning: can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved, like the number of lives saved, instead of monetary benefit is called ______________
questions.solution:
Cost-effective analysis: The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the application in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. However, even cost-effective analysis is not possible in many cases.

other options:

Cost-benefit analysis: The economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to determine whether a given program is economically sound and to select the best out of several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits in the health field, as a result of a particular program, cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. We generally express the benefit in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Input-output analysis: How much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, "input" refers to all health service activities which consume resources (manpower, money, materials and time); and "output" refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organisational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: The type of joint involved in the following movement of the neck is?
questions.solution:
The joint for side-to-side movements in the neck is the atlanto-axial joint which is a type of pivot joint.

Movement in the atlanto-axial joints are simultaneous and consists almost exclusively of rotation around the axis, which helps a person look to the right and left. 

  • The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.
  • The orientation and shape of the atlanto-occipital joints allow mainly for flexion–extension, which has a total range of about 15°.

Pivot joint:

In pivot joint, one bone rotates in relation to another bone.

This is a uniaxial joint, and thus rotation is the only motion allowed at a pivot joint.

Eg:

  • Atlantoaxial joint: the first cervical (C1) vertebra (atlas) rotates around the dens, the upward projection from the second cervical (C2) vertebra (axis). This allows the head to rotate from side to side as when shaking the head “no.”
  • The proximal radioulnar joint is a pivot joint formed by the head of the radius and its articulation with the ulna. This joint allows for the radius to rotate along its length during pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

questions.text: A 27 year old woman at 17 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge. She has no other complaints. On examination, greenish frothy discharge is present. No laboratory facilities are available. How would you proceed with management?

choices.text: Local treatment with Clotrimazole vaginal pessary
Give oral secnidazole to the patient
Treat the patient and her husband with acyclovir

questions.solution:
The patient should be administered single dose of secnidazole 2g orally as she has trichomonas vaginitis and she is in her second trimester of pregnancy.

This patient in her second trimester of pregnancy has greenish, frothy vaginal discharge mostly has trichomoniasis. However, since laboratory tests are not available, it cannot be confirmed. Using the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, she should be treated with oral secnidazole.

Alternate option is to use Tab. Tinidazole 500 mg orally. twice daily for 5 days.

Metronidazole pessary is preferred in the first trimester of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text: A 23-year-old primi comes to the clinic for her review on the 22nd week of gestation. Her BP was 140/80mmHg 2 weeks back and right now it is 150/80mmHg. Pt was started on Methyldopa. Which of the following receptors does the drug act on?
questions.solution:
Methyldopa acts on α2 receptors.

Methyldopa is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent that is converted into alpha-methyl-norepinephrine in the brain that activates α2 receptors in the brain to decrease central sympathetic outflow.

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBS
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside

Antihypertensives found safer in pregnancy :

  • Labetalol
  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardioselective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: may be used as a last choice.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common nerves affected in nasopharyngeal carcinoma in descending order of frequency are CN V > CN VI > CN IX > CN X > CN XII.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also called Guangdong tumor.
  • Commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
    • Hearing loss
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis
    • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. (V more than VI)

 Nasopharyngeal cancer can cause:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube block)
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal/facial neuralgia (involvement of CN V) and
  • Palatal paralysis (CN X)

This is collectively called Trotter’s triad.

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text: The structure (Red Arrow) shown in the image develops from _______
questions.solution:
The arrow depicts the neurohypophysis which develops from the diencephalon.

The pituitary has two major parts, the neurohypophysis and adenohypophysis, which differ in their origin, structure and function.

The neurohypophysis is a diencephalic downgrowth connected with the hypothalamus.

The adenohypophysis is an ectodermal derivative of the stomatodeum.

questions.text: Keratosis obturans is caused by which of the following:
questions.solution:
Keratosis obturans is due to desquamated epithelial cells.

Keratosis obturans:

  • Normally, epithelium from surface of tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall.
  • Failure of this migration or obstruction to migration caused by wax may lead to accumulation of the epithelial plug in the deep meatus.
  • Appears as pearly white mass occluding the canal.
  • This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerve may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • Must be removed similar to wax

questions.text: Lumbar hemivertebra results due to the abnormal development of:
questions.solution:
Lumbar hemivertebra results due to the abnormal development of sclerotomes. 

The vertebral column and ribs develop from the sclerotome compartments of the somite. 

As development continues, the sclerotome portion of each somite also undergoes a process called resegmentatíon. Resegmentation occurs when the caudal half of each sclerotome grows into and fuses with the cephalic half of each subjacent sclerotome. 

Thus, each vertebra is formed from the combination of the caudal half of one somite and the cranial half of its neighbor. Note: Patterning of the shapes of the different vertebrae is regulated by HOX genes.

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?
questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone acts through aquaporin channel 2.

ADH binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.

Clinical note: Lithium, which is often used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene.

questions.text: The following Immunofluorescence pattern is seen in a patient who presented to the OPD with hematuria. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. Electron microscopy revealed the presence of electron-dense deposits predominantly in the mesangium. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details and immunofluorescence (IF) pattern are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger disease).

IgA nephropathy:

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide, characterized by recurrent hematuria/nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangial regions.

Microscopy:

  • Light microscopy: Glomeruli may be normal or may show mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation (mesangio-proliferative glomerulonephritis [MPGN]); normal basement membrane thickness.
  • Immunofluorescence: Mesangial deposition of IgA, often with C3 and properdin and lesser amounts of IgG or IgM
  • Electron microscopy: Presence of electron-dense deposits, predominantly in the mesangium.

Also know: Henoch–Schönlein purpura, a systemic disorder of children presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients. This has led to the concept that IgA nephropathy and Henoch–Schönlein purpura are manifestations of the same disease.

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except:

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU) and tryptophan deficiency is not a feature of this disorder. PKU is caused by the deficiency of an enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. 

Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis. Ferric chloride test is also used as a screening test for PKU. Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard investigation.

questions.text: The ability of a test to avoid false negative error is:

choices.text: Directly proportional to the width of confidence interval and inversely proportional to sample size
Directly proportional to β and directly proportional to sampling error
Directly proportional to sample size and inversely proportional to sampling error
Inversely proportional to the width of confidence interval and directly proportional to sampling error

questions.solution:
The ability of a test to avoid false negative error (type II or β error) is called the Power of the Test (“the ability of a test to reject a null hypothesis when it is false”).

It is expressed as 1 - β.

Thus,

A test’s power will increase if

  • β error decreases
  • Width of the Confidence interval (I.e., the margin of error) decreases
  • Sampling error decreases
  • Sample size increases

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was obtained not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the size of the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized population mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman working in a chemical industry is not given protective masks and goggles. The employer is liable under?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the employer is liable under the Factories (Amendment) Act, 1987.

The Factories Act, 1948 has prescribed in detail the precautions to be taken for ensuring the safety of the workers. Including protective devices (like goggles) and precautions against dangerous fumes.

The Factories Act was amended in the year 1987. It stipulates pre-employment examination as a pre-placement procedure, and statutory periodic medical examination for a job in hazardous areas.

Other options:

  • The Maternity Act, 2017: it enhances the duration of paid maternity leave.
  • The Employees State Insurance Act, 1948: It provides for certain cash and medical benefits to industrial employees in case of sickness, maternity, and employment injury.
  • Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna, 2005: It provides an unemployment allowance for the employees covered under the ESI Scheme.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: After a fatty meal, which of the following lipoproteins are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency?
questions.solution:
After a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols).

This is called a nascent chylomicron which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL is remodeled into mature chylomicron.

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy.

Clinical correlate: Patients with lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II deficiency (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) hence show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma, after a fatty meal.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, TG and cholesterol Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old renal transplant patient presented with difficulty in vision. The fundoscopy was done and is shown below. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing the disease?

choices.text: It causes interstitial pneumonitis in bone marrow transplant patients
Congenital infection can cause intrauterine growth retardation
Foscarnet is the treatment of choice for the infection of eye
Serological assays are important for immunocompromised patients

questions.solution:
CMV retinitis is the most probable diagnosis as the patient is immunocompromised (transplant recipient) and the fundoscopy shows patchy areas of retinal necrosis with irregular borders and overlying retinal hemorrhages.

  • The serological assay is not informative in the case of the immunocompromised patient and PCR assay is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • CMV mostly causes infection in immunocompromised patients such as transplant recipients and AIDS. The most common infections are interstitial pneumonitis, gastroenteritis, esophagitis, and retinitis.
  • Ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir are approved for treatment of CMV retinitis in patients with AIDS.

questions.text: A person presents to the emergency department with suspected poisoning due to ingestion of arsenic containing pesticides 24 hours ago. Which of the following is not a likely finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mees lines are unlikely to be found in a patient with arsenic ingestion 24 hours ago. 

Features of acute arsenic poisoning

  • Acute toxicity typically starts in the gastrointestinal system with severe watery diarrhea (like cholera)
  • QTc prolongation and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute encephalopathy
  • Renal injury with Acute Tubular Necrosis
  • Garlic odor of breath and stools

Mees lines (horizontal 1 to 2 mm white lines on the nails, also called transverse leukonychia), which occur from a disturbance in the nail matrix keratinization. It usually takes at least 30 days for the Mees lines to become visible. It may be seen 4 to 6 weeks after an acute arsenic ingestion. These can also be seen in Thallium poisoning.

Mees' lines:

questions.text: The following image shows an ovarian follicle. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Cells of the layer marked ‘A’ is actively stimulated by FSH
Cells of the layer marked ‘A’ synthesise androgens from the cholestrol
Cells of the layer marked ‘B’ do not have receptor for LH
Cells of the layer marked ‘B’ lack the enzyme aromatase

questions.solution:
The region marked ‘A’ is theca interna and the region marked ‘B’ is granulosa cell layer. Synthesis of estrogen is mainly due to the interaction between granulosa cells and theca cells. In an overview, the theca interna cells synthesise progesterone and androgens from the cholestrol which subsequently are coverted to estrogens by the granulosa cells.

Salient features of theca interna cells:

  • The theca interna cells are actively stimulated by LH (Luetinising hormone).
  • They are involved in the synthesis of progestogens and androgens.
  • Estrogens are not formed in theca cells as they lack the enzyme aromatase.

Salient features of granulosa cells:

  • The granulosa cells have receptors for both LH and FSH.
  • They convert the androgens provided by  the theca cells to estrogens with the help of an enzyme aromatase.
  • The following image shows interaction between the theca cell and granulosa cell in the synthesis of estrogen:

questions.text: While working in a family planning center, you have been advising couples for contraceptive methods. The curious interns ask you to teach them regarding the pearl index mentioned in a learning poster in the clinic. Which of the following points related to this would be incorrect?

choices.text: It is a method to measure the contraceptive efficacy
Total accidental pregnancies doesn't include abortions
Total months of exposure is calculated after deducting certain duration for abortion and full term pregnancy
The number 1200 indicates the number of months in 100 years

questions.solution:
Total accidental pregnancies include every form of conception, like live births, stillbirths, or abortions, or have not yet terminated.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure.

Total months of exposure in the denominator is calculated after deducting 10 months for a full-term pregnancy, and 4 months for an abortion.

The number 1200 in the formula indicates the number of months in 100 years.

The pearl index is usually based on a specific duration of exposure (usually a year), therefore it cannot accurately compare methods at different durations of exposure.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index:

  • The pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).
  • Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure
  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that is used as the numerator must include every known conception, whatever its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher order births.

questions.text: A known asthmatic comes to ER with breathlessness. On examination, BP 110/70mmHg ; PR 95 bpr; RR 22/min ;  O2 sats 98% on room air. Expiratory wheeze heard all over the chest on auscultation. Patient was started on β2 sympathomimetics. Which of the following is not an adverse effect of the drug?
questions.solution:
β2 sympathomimetic are drugs like Salbutamol, salmeterol and at large doses can result in hyperglycemia, and not hypoglycemia.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists:

  • Muscle tremors: Direct effect on beta 2 receptors in skeletal muscles and due to hypokalemia
  • Tachycardia: Direct effect on cardiac beta 2 receptors, indirect sympathetic stimulation due to vasodilator action on beta 2 receptors (Option A)
  • Hypokalemia: Direct effect on skeletal muscle uptake of K+ ions (Option C)
  • Hypoxemia
  • Tolerance: Desensitization on long-term use (Option B)

Note: Adverse effect profile is less likely with inhalational drugs

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the OPD with headaches and high blood pressure. On investigation,  increased aldosterone levels with low renin levels are seen and a diagnosis of Conn's syndrome is made. Excess secretion of aldosterone can cause all except ________
questions.solution:
Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually <4-6 mEq/L rise in plasma sodium. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.

Conn’s syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone producing tumour of the zona glomerulosa, causing:

  • Loss of potassium by the kidneys leading to hypokalemia.
  • Mild metabolic alkalosis.
  • A slight increase in extracellular fluid volume and blood volume.
  • A modest increase in plasma sodium concentration.
  • Hypertension.

questions.text: What is the dosage of Vitamin A given for a 2 year old baby with keratomalacia?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
The recommended dosage for a 2 year old child with keratomalacia is 2,00,000 IU to be given immediately, followed by the same age specific dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks.

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration

XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ER after a blunt facial trauma following an RTA. There is malocclusion. On examination, there is bruising over the palate. A plain CT revealed craniofacial dysjunction. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Ecchymosis in the palate in the region of the greater palatine arteries is termed Guerin’s sign.

Other options:

  • Battle’s sign: Ecchymosis overlying the mastoid indicative of a temporal bone fracture.
  • Destot’s sign: Superficial hematoma presenting as an ecchymosis located above the inguinal ligament or in the scrotum or thigh. It is indicative of pelvic fractures.
  • Fox’s sign: Bruising over the upper aspect of the thigh indicative of acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Le fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture
 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea
 
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea
